summary: The EBA Guidelines on credit risk management practices and accounting for expected credit losses (EBA/GL/2017/06) are consistently referenced and applied across various EBA guidelines and the Basel Framework. Several documents reiterate the requirement for credit institutions to follow these guidelines for estimating loss allowances, managing impairments and write-offs for non-performing exposures (NPEs) and forborne exposures (FBEs), defining default, and implementing appropriate credit risk management practices including those related to expected credit losses (ECLs). The Basel Framework also broadly emphasizes sound credit risk management processes and provisioning levels, referencing the BCBS guidance on ECL which the EBA guidelines aim to align with. Specific overlaps were found where other EBA guidelines mandate adherence to the original document's principles or where regulatory frameworks discuss the application of ECL accounting standards for credit risk management and disclosure.

overlaps.excerpt1: Regarding the comments on the level playing field, the EBA acknowledges that the BCBS guidance is more relevant to internationally active banks and that IFRS and US GAAP requirements on ECL are not fully converged. However, as in the BCBS guidance, sections 4.1, 4.2 and 4.4 apply to all credit institutions applying an expected credit loss accounting framework, while section 4.3 is relevant to credit institutions applying IFRS 9. Therefore, these guidelines should provide to some extent a level playing field across those credit institutions applying an expected credit loss accounting framework (such as IFRS or US GAAP) and also across jurisdictions that apply either the EBA guidelines or the BCBS guidance.

To achieve this objective, credit risk disclosures shall provide: (a) information about an entity's credit risk management practices and how they relate to the recognition and measurement of expected credit losses, including the methods, assumptions and information used to measure expected credit losses; (b) quantitative and qualitative information that allows users of financial statements to evaluate the amounts in the financial statements arising from expected credit losses, including changes in the amount of expected credit losses and the reasons for those changes; and (c) information about an entity's credit risk exposure (ie the credit risk inherent in an entity's financial assets and commitments to extend credit) including significant credit risk concentrations. overlaps.explanation: Excerpt 1 from the EBA guidelines discusses the application of an expected credit loss accounting framework (like IFRS 9) by credit institutions. Excerpt 2 from IFRS 7 (as amended by Regulation EU 2023/1803) directly mandates entities to provide disclosures about their credit risk management practices as they relate to the recognition and measurement of expected credit losses, specifically mentioning IFRS 9 concepts like 'significant increase in credit risk', 'definitions of default', 'credit-impaired financial assets', and 'write-off policy'. This constitutes an overlap because the EBA guidelines provide guidance on these practices, and the IFRS regulation mandates disclosure of how entities implement them under IFRS 9, directly addressing the same regulatory subject matter and functional context of ECL accounting and credit risk management.

overlaps.excerpt2: It is expected that by the time of implementation of these guidelines many institutions will already apply IRFS 9 instead of current accounting standards. Since these new rules are significantly different from the currently used IAS 39 and introduce the concept of expected credit losses, which is new in the accounting framework, the EBA considers it necessary to specify the treatment of provisions under IFRS 9 - despite those rules not having entered into effect. It is consequently proposed that as a general rule all exposures classified as Stage 3, i.e. exposures treated as credit-impaired under IFRS 9, should be treated as defaulted. Only a few exceptions from that rule have been specified and these include: " exposures where 180 days past due are used instead of 90 days on the basis of the discretion provided in Article 178(1)(b) of the CRR; " the application of the materiality threshold in accordance with Article 178(2)(d) of the CRR where it is not used for the purpose of classification of exposures to Stage 3; " technical past due situations; " exposures to central governments, local authorities and public sector entities that are under specific treatment as described above. If in the cases listed above the 90 days past due criterion is used for accounting purposes and credit- impaired status would be the only indication of default, such exposures may remain in non-defaulted status. overlaps.explanation: Excerpt 1 discusses the EBA guidelines' relevance to credit institutions applying IFRS 9 for ECL. Excerpt 2 explicitly states the EBA's position on the treatment of provisions under IFRS 9 for defining default, particularly that 'all exposures classified as Stage 3, i.e. exposures treated as credit-impaired under IFRS 9, should be treated as defaulted'.
